etymologies: late Middle English: from Old French, literally ‘dead pledge’, from mort (from Latin mortuus ‘dead’) + gage ‘pledge’

definitions: a legal agreement by which a bank or other creditor lends money at interest in exchange for taking title of the debtor's property, with the condition that the conveyance of title becomes void upon the payment of the debt

examples.text: I put down a hundred thousand in cash and took out a mortgage for the rest

shortDefinitions: loan obtained with property as security

definitions: a loan obtained through the conveyance of property as security

examples.text: I put down a hundred thousand in cash and took out a mortgage for the rest

shortDefinitions: amount of money borrowed in mortgage

definitions: a deed effecting the conditions of a mortgage.
convey (a property) to a creditor as security on a loan

examples.text: the estate was mortgaged up to the hilt

shortDefinitions: convey property to creditor as security on loan

definitions: expose to future risk or constraint for the sake of immediate advantage

examples.text: some people worry that selling off federal assets mortgages the country's future

shortDefinitions: expose to future risk for immediate advantage
